editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: To the right Reuerend father in God, and right honourable Lord, Doctor Iohn Iegon, Lord Bi≈øhop of Norwich, the continuance, and daily increa≈øe of all tho≈øe heauenly vertues and graces, which the Apo≈øtle S. Paul requireth in a Bi≈øhop, 1. Tim. 3.2.
div.p:
RIght reuerend father, and very honourable Lord, be≈øides many other weightie rea≈øons, whereby I haue beene mooued to commend this ≈øimple pre≈øent vnto your Lord≈øhips fauour, which it is not nece≈ø≈øarie nor conuenient to make all the world acquainted with (it is enough that your Lord≈øhip priuately doth take knowledge of them) it may be ≈øufficient openly to profe≈ø≈øe thus much; That whereas my ≈øelfe, with all the re≈øt of my brethren & fellow mini≈øters, were in our countrie, and in all the re≈øt of your L. Dioces of Norfolke and Suffolke, the la≈øt ≈øommer inioyned by your letters ≈øent to your officers to that ende (according
to the order ≈øet downe before in print, by the authoritie of the Kings mo≈øt excellent maie≈øtie) to come to the Church euery we ‚Ä¢ ke vpon the wedne≈ødaies and fridaies, with the re≈øt of our people & flocke committed vnto vs: there and then to be occupied in praier and fa≈øting, to intreat the Lord for our ≈øinnes, and for the ≈øinnes of the re≈øt in this land: that ≈øo his heauie hand, which by the pe≈øtilence was then very ≈øharpely, and that a long time ≈øtretched out in many cheife cities and towns of this realme, and namely, of this your L. Dioces, as Norwich, and Yarmouth, and ≈øome other might be called in at his appointed time,Sam. 24.16. as it was in the daies of king Dauid. Whereby it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that both here, and in many places els, there was much more preaching & hearing of the word of God, and praying vnto him, then was before, and otherwi≈øe would haue beene. So that by meanes of the ≈øtraite charge laid vpon all by your L. letter, there was much good done in this countrie at that time, the fruite whereof
I hope, remaineth vnto this day. For though the booke containing the cau≈øe and order of tho≈øe fa≈øts, which was made by ≈øome of the cheife gouernours in the Church of England, and was authorized by the Kings Highne≈ø≈øe, did (as I take it) not onely giue leaue vnto all places publikely to meete vpon the≈øe aboue named daies to the≈øe ends, but did inioyne them to it: and ≈øo all men might haue taken knowledge of it, and of their dutie therein from thence: e≈øpecially when the cau≈øe of it (namely ≈øo grieuous, and ≈øo vniuer≈øall a plague) was ≈øo notorious, that it could not be hid from any: yet it was found too true by experience in many places, that vntill ≈øuch time as men were further called vpon by your Lord≈øhips letter, full of great and weightie rea≈øons to per≈øwade thereunto, that neither many mini≈øters had any care to call vpon their people to ≈øo holy and nece≈ø≈øarie a ≈øeruice, nor the people any great deuotion to come: So ≈ølowe are men vnto any part of Gods ≈øeruice, yea though it doth ≈øo greatly coÃÑ cerne
them, e≈øpecially to this principall part of it in fa≈øting and praier (which hath beene very long out of v≈øe) that they had neede not onely lightly to be called vpon, but with many ≈øtrong coards violently hailed vnto it: though vnto all matters of the world, they are ≈øo forward and ha≈øtie, that they runne of their own accord, and none can ≈øtay them. Hereupon it hath come to pa≈ø≈øe, that a great part of the good, that this way hath beene done vnto the people of God, and ≈øeruice to his maie≈øtie, is to be imputed vnto your lord≈øhips diligent care, who did ≈øo timely, and effectually ≈øtirre vp men vnto it: e≈øpecially in re≈øpect of tho≈øe cheife places & others, vnder your Lord≈øhips iuri≈ødiction, which then were greatly ≈øubiect vnto this vi≈øitation, as well as other parts of this land, neither are they all of them yet free from it. Therefore the≈øe beeing part of my labours at that time, they are in ≈øome ≈øort due vnto your Lord≈øhip, by who≈øe means I receiued incouragement thereunto, as others did to the like. And I haue pre≈øumed
to pre≈øent them vnto your Lord≈øhip, that by them you may ≈øee, and by one may iudge of the re≈øt, how readie we are, and ≈øhall be, to yeild obedience to all your L. godly proceedings: promi≈øing for my ≈øelfe, and pre≈øuming of the re≈øt that when we ≈øhall be likewi≈øe commanded (which we expect, and hope for in time) to keepe ≈øolemne dayes of thank≈øgiuing for the mitigating of this plague in ≈øo great mea≈øure in the mo≈øt places, and for the cleane taking of it away in many, we will be, by the grace of God, as ready to performe that part of ≈øeruice, as we haue beene forward vnto this. And in the meane ≈øea≈øon according to our bounden duty we will indeauour not only priuatly to be thankfull vnto God, but vpon all ≈øuch daies, as we haue our publike a≈ø≈øemblies, to doe it in ≈øome part, and to call vpon our people to be thankfull to God with vs, both in hart, words, and life: lea≈øt the Lord for our vnthankfulnes doe returne vpon vs with the ≈øame, or ≈øome other great puni≈øhment of his. Which
we haue ≈øo much the more cau≈øe to feare, vnles we thus ≈øeeke to preuent it, becau≈øe the late memory of ≈øo great a worke, both of iu≈øtice in ≈øending the plague, and of mercy in taking it away, is not ≈øo fre≈øh & effectuall with all men, nay with very few, as it ≈øhould: but they like to vngratious children ≈øo ≈øoone forget the rodd, as it is off their back. And ≈øeeing by the≈øe your Lord≈øhip may take knowledge, that by your godly incitation many were made more painfull in their callings (at the lea≈øt for that time) then otherwi≈øe they would have beene, whereby al≈øo God was more honoured, and the people more in≈øtructed: your Lord≈øhip will according to that high place, wherein God hath placed you, e≈øpecially to that end, take all opportunities by word and writing ≈øtill to incite all men to be zealous and feruent in the worke of the mini≈øtery: by giuing all good incouragement vnto the painfull labourers in Gods harue≈øt, and by quickning vp them that are any way ≈ølothfull and negligent, and by di≈øcountenancing
them that are altogether careles and idle, and by ≈øtopping vp the pa≈ø≈øage vnto al idol ≈øheapherds & hirelings, who ≈øeeke the fleece and not the flock: who≈øe right arme as it is cleane withred vp, and their right eye vtterly darkned ≈øo as the Prophet ≈øaith they haue neither will,Zach. 11.17. nor abilitie to doe any good in the Church of God. That ≈øo not only the go≈øpell may ≈øtill more and more be purely preached in this your Lord≈øhips Dioces, (as now by the grace of God it is, and hath beene a long time by many learned & great men) but that the people in all places may be compelled diligently to frequent it: & not only them≈øelues to yeeld obedience vnto it, but to haue their children & ≈øeruants,Act. 10.2. euen their whole families willingly catechi≈øed: that they may feare God with all their hou≈øehoulds. That ≈øo we may ble≈ø≈øe god, not only for your comming among vs, but much more for your continuance with vs, and ouer vs: and pray to him for you (as we doe, and mind to doe) that the Lord will long pre≈øerue you zealous of
his glory, and carefull of the good of that part of his church, ouer which the holy gho≈øt hath made you ouer≈øeer,ap. 20.28. which al≈øo Ie≈øus Chri≈øt hath purcha≈øed, not with gold or ≈øiluer, but with his owne mo≈øt pretious blood. That ≈øo among the re≈øt of his good and faithfull ≈øeruants, who haue v≈øed their talents well,ib. 25.2 ‚Ä¢ . he may giue you a full reward in the kingdome of heauen, who hath ≈øaid, if thou loue me feed my ≈øheepe, if thou loue me, feed my lambes.
‚Ä¢ . 21.1 ‚Ä¢ . For though the daily exerci≈øes of the word of God ≈øhould be ≈øufficient of them≈øelues, to purcha≈øe credit and reuerence to theÃÑ≈øelues with all ≈øorts of people, as to the mo≈øt holy ordinances of the eternall God; and the great wantes, that are in all men, ≈øhould driue them to ≈øeeke to them continually as to the meanes of their ≈øaluation, whereby all their wantes might be ≈øupplied: yet ≈øuch is the irreligion in many, and the want of feeling in others, that they are no more forward vnto any part of Gods ≈øeruice, or of the meanes of their owne ≈øaluation, then authority doth
compell them. Thus a≈ø≈øuring my ≈øelfe, that your later deedes will be an≈øwerable to the≈øe good beginnings, or rather happy proceedings; yea that they will goe farre beyond them in all godly zeale, I comfort my ≈øelfe, with the re≈øt of my brethren in the daily expectation and hope of it: praying to god,P≈øal. 69.9. that the zeale of his hou≈øe may euen con≈øume you: that ≈øo you waxing old in all well doing,Prou. 16.31. your age may be ≈øo much the more honorable, beeing found in the way of righteou≈ønes. And ≈øo not doutibng of your Lord≈øhips fauourable acceptatioÃÑ of the≈øe my poore endeauours, I leaue them to your fatherly and honorable protection, and my ≈øelfe, & my ≈øeruice to your continuall commandement, very humbly taking my leaue. Norton in Suffolke. 30. Aprill. 1604.

div.head: To the godly and Christian Reader, the daily increa≈øe of that true godline≈ø≈øe, which hath the promi≈øe of the life pre≈øent, and of that that is to come, 1. Tim. 4.8.
div.p:
WHen as of late this holy exerci≈øe of fa≈øting, was by publike authoritie, not without iu≈øt cau≈øe impo≈øed vpoÃÑ vs (welbeloued fathers and brethren) I thought it conuenient, or rather nece≈ø≈øarie for that people, which then I had to deale with (and haue still) fir≈øt of all to make them acquainted with the nature of it, not ≈øo much by preaching of fa≈øting out of ≈øome one text, (which could not very fitly haue beene done) as by deliuering vnto them in ≈øundrie ≈øermons the whole doctrine of it orderly, out of many places of holy Sc ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pture, or rather out of the whole word of God indifferently. That ≈øo they might be the more willing to ≈øubmit them≈øelues vnto it, when they did ≈øee cleerely what they ≈øhould doe, and
‚Ä¢ l≈øo that they doe it in ≈øome good mea≈øure ‚Ä¢ cceptable to God, and comfortably to theÃÑ ≈øelues, when they perceaued after what manner they ≈øhould doe it. And thus in making of the≈øe ≈øhort treati≈øes and Homilies at the first I had re≈øpect only vnto them. Since I coÃÑ≈øidering on the one ≈øide the great ignorance that is in mo≈øt places, as of all other partes of gods ≈øeruice which are ordinary ≈øo mo≈øt of all this, which is extraordinary, e≈øpecially becau≈øe it is, and hath beene ≈øo much out of v≈øe: and then waying on the other ≈øide, that there may be hereafter great cau≈øe offered vnto vs againe of v≈øing this holy & excellent ordinance of god, either publikely in many places, or priuately in more, ≈øeeing that this vi≈øitatioÃÑ of the plague doth ≈øo linger, like vnto the leapro≈øy which ≈øometime did hang long in the how≈øes of the Iewes, and ≈øoe doth very ≈øhortly, or not at all wholy depart from ≈øome places: be≈øides tho≈øe new cha≈øti≈øements, which we know not how many or how ≈øoone they may come vpon vs: I thought ≈øince, that both for the≈øe, and for other
cau≈øes the≈øe my labours might be not wholly vnprofitable to all tho≈øe, that are well minded. And thought I cannot be ignorant that there are many and godly and learned ≈øermons and treati≈øes, both in engli≈øh and latine, already extant of this argument, and ≈øo my indeauour after them may ≈øeeme ≈øuperfluous: yet all things con≈øidered, I doubt not, but that ≈øome may ≈øtand in neede of the≈øe al≈øo. For as I mu≈øt needes confe≈ø≈øe, that I haue read the former, & indeauoured to follow ≈øome of theÃÑ: ≈øo I leaue the learneder ≈øort to ≈øuch of them, as them≈øelues ≈øhall be≈øt like: only this for the more ignorant ≈øort I haue aymed at, to make the whole doctrine of fa≈øting ea≈øy and plaine, that they might with facility vnder≈øtand what god requireth of them in the day of fa≈øt, and how they ought to behaue them ≈øelues therein: And to that end I haue ≈øet downe euery thing orderly, & at large, & therefore the more clearly: and not ≈øcholastically and ≈øhortly (as ≈øome haue done) and by that meanes the more ob≈øcurely, e≈øpecially vnto the vulgar ≈øort:
and I haue ≈øhewed the practi≈øe of euery particular, out of the Scripture, ≈øetting downe at large the wordes of euery text for the capacity of the ≈øimplest, and oftentimes for the more ea≈øines and plainnes, hauing recour≈øe of purpo≈øe to the ≈øelfe ≈øame texts, rather then making choi≈øe of new, which vainly might happily haue bread ≈øome ob≈øcuritie Which kind of writing if it may ≈øeeme to bring tediou≈ønes vnto the learned eares, they must con≈øider, that fir≈øt I preached the≈øe ≈øermons to the meaner ≈øort, men not brought vp in learning and ≈øo did apply my ≈øelfe in handling of this doctrine vnto their capacity, leading them on in it according to their owne pace (which is rightly to diuide the word of God: and in his how≈øe (as a wi≈øe steward) to giue vnto euery one of them their owne food in due ≈øea≈øon) and ≈øince, euen as they were then preached, I haue publi≈øhed them for their ≈øakes e≈øpecially, and ≈øo haue deliuered them as milke, for all tho≈øe that are but babes and children in Christ. And therefore if any of the≈øe
≈øhall receiue any benefit by them, I haue attained vnto the end of my labours, though the other ≈øort be not holpen by them one whit. For which I will pray vnto God, euen as I de≈øire all you, to whome the≈øe pre≈øents ≈øhall come, to pray for me: and the Lord heare vs all for our ≈øelues, and one of vs for an other: and his well beloued ≈øonne Ie≈øu ‚Ä¢ Christ our only mediatour for vs all: that we may liue and dye in his faith and in his feare: that ≈øo the ≈øame Christ may be vnto vs life, and in death aduantage. Norton, in Suffolke.

Euen as a Phy≈øitian ≈øhoulde pre≈øcribe vnto his patient, & that yerely vpon ≈øuch a day of the moneth, or weeke hee ≈øhould take ≈øuch a purgation; when as it may fall out, that then hee is in con≈øumption, and ≈øo had more need of ≈øome cordiall electuary, or re≈øtoratiue medicine, than of anie purgations: and if any ≈øhould ≈øo vnadui≈øedly pre≈øcribe, we woulde count him a foole rather then a Phy≈øitian. Now further we are to con≈øider how we ≈øhould be≈øtow this time of fa≈øting, and wherein we are to be occupied in the daie of fa≈øt.The time of fasting is „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of th ‚Ä¢ Sabbath. And for the better vnder≈øtanding of that, wee mu≈øt knowe thus much, that the time of fa≈øting, how long ≈øoeuer, whether it bee but one daie, or more, is alwaies of the nature of the Sabbath: therfore looke how we ought to be≈øtow the Sabbath in re≈øting from the ordinarie labors, and workes of our callings, and from all kinde of recreations and pa≈øtimes much more, and come to the Church, and be occupied in Gods ≈øeruice, publikely and priuately, ≈øo ought we to do vpon the day of fa≈øting. And that we might be a≈ø≈øured heereof, fir≈øt we doe read, that this day as it is of that nature, ≈øo it hath that name giuen vnto it, for it is called a Sabbath:Leu. 23.23 This ≈øhal be vnto you a Sabbath of re≈øt, yee ≈øhal humble your ≈øoules: in the ninth daie of the month at eeuen, from eeuen to
eeuen yee ≈øhall celebrate your Sabbath: where twi≈øe in one ver≈øe Mo≈øes calleth it a Sabbath. Secondlie it is called a Sabbath of re≈øt, and they are willed to re≈øt their Sabbath, to ≈øhewe that vpon that daie, (as vpon the ordinarie Sabbath day) they ≈øhould re≈øt from the labours of their calling: and more particularly they are forbidden to doe anie kinde of worke vpon that daie:Leu. 23.28. as it is ≈øaide, Yee ≈øhall doe no worke that ≈øame daie, for it is a day of reconciliation, to make attonement for you before the Lorde your God. to doe with them, and not onely from their hands, but their mindes from them, according to the ≈øame ≈øtrictne≈ø≈øe that they are bounde vnto vpon the Sabbath daie. In≈øomuch that if there bee occa≈øion to keepe a fa≈øt in the time of harue≈øt, or ≈øeed-time, or any other time of bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, ≈øo manie as doe profe≈ø≈øe to keepe it, mu≈øt altogither ab≈øtaine from all ≈øuch workes, as were otherwi≈øe not onely lawfull, but nece≈ø≈øarie. But ≈øetting all ≈øuch ca≈øes of nece≈ø≈øitie a≈øide, all men ought wholy vpon the≈øe daies to re≈øt from their labours; which the Lorde hath ≈øtraightly forbidden, with the denunciation of a fearefull cur≈øe, that he will a≈ø≈øuredly bring vpon al tho≈øe that breake it, euen that he will cut them off from his people.

And be≈øides this re≈øting from worke (which is nece≈ø≈øarily required) wee ought to be≈øtow the whole day in the publicke and priuate exerci≈øes of the wor≈øhip and ≈øeruice of God;We mu≈øt be

So likewi≈øe Mo≈øes ≈øpeaking of the day of fa≈øt, ≈øayth, It ≈øhalbe an holy conuocation vnto you, and you ≈øhal humble your ≈øoules, and offer ≈øacrifices made by fire vnto the Lord: where he doeth not onely ≈øay, that their a≈ø≈øemblies

Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, & Chenani, who cried with a loud voice vnto the Lord their God: and they ≈øtood vp, and ≈øaid, Prai≈øe the Lord your God for euer and euer; and let them prai≈øe thy glorious name, O God, which excelleth about al thank≈øgiuing & prai≈øe: where wee ≈øee that there were manie that prayed vnto God, and exhorted the people, which could not be all at once, becau≈øe of di≈øorder and confu≈øion,

In the popi≈øh fa≈øting dayes worke was ordinarily permitted.And here againe we haue iu≈øt cau≈øe to finde fault with the popi≈øh pretended fa≈øtes, who as in manie other things they ≈øwarued from the word of God, ≈øo in this one point they came nothing neere it: for vpon their fa≈øting daies there was no re≈øtraint of worke, but it was lawfull for them to followe their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, as vpon any other day, & they that profe≈ø≈øed to keepe it mo≈øt deuoutly, yet did not leaue their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe vntill noone, and then not wholly neither, for be≈øides dre≈ø≈øing vp of hou≈øes, preparing of linen again≈øt the

div.head: HOMIL. VII.

argument.p: The ≈øeuenth Homilie intreateth of the ≈øeuerall kindes or ≈øorts of fa≈øts, whereof the one is priuate, and the other publike: and first of priuate fastings, and how to behaue our ≈øelues in them: and how they ought to be intertained into mens hou≈øes: and for what cau≈øes; and what great good may come thereby: and what liberty the Gouernors haue in appointing of them aboue all the rest of the familie.

div.head: A direction for Prayer: Fit and conuenient for all tho≈øe, that being ignorant or vnacquainted with priuate prayer, are de≈øirous to pray by them≈øelues.
div.p: FIr≈øt let your ordinary praiers be ≈øudden: but take ≈øome time beforehand by meditation to prepare your ≈øelfe vnto praier, and let this be the beginning of your praier, that God would prepare your heart vnto praier. Eccl. 4.17. Math. 6.6. P≈øal. 108.1.

Then make an humble confe≈ø≈øion of your ≈øinnes vnto God; and that both generally that you haue bene conceiued and borne in, and continually liued in; breaking his holie law daily, in thought, worde, and deed: and of ≈øome more particularly, wherin you haue mo≈øt offended
him in any part of your life: P≈øa. 40.12. & 51.4.5. & 32.5. Dan. 9.5.6. Acknowledge vnto God from the bottome of your hart, that for the≈øe ≈øinnes of yours, is mo≈øt due vnto you his heauie wrath and indignation, and all tho≈øe puni≈øhments and plagues, which in his Law he hath threatned to bring vpon ≈øinners, both in this life & the life to come: and more ≈øpecially iudge your ≈øelfe mo≈øt woorthie of tho≈øe particular iudgements, that any waies you are in danger of, or that you are pre≈øently in Ezr. 9.6.15. Pray that in the con≈øcience of this fearefull e≈øtate of yours, you may be humbled before God in that maner and mea≈øure, that ≈øo great a ≈øinner ≈øhould be: and that in all humilitie you might ca≈øt downe your ≈øelfe in your owne conceit before God, and his holy Angels, and all men, in re≈øpect of the de≈øert of your

To this end de≈øire God to giue you a broken and a contrite ≈øpirite, that your hart being ≈øoft and tender, his word, both the Law and the cur≈øes thereof, and the Go≈øpell with the promi≈øes of the ≈øame, together with all his workes of iu≈øtice and mercy, vpon your ≈øelfe and vpon others might worke on your con≈øcience, as they ought to do. Thus groaning vnder the heauie burden of them, de≈øire God earne≈øtly for Chri≈øts ≈øake to ea≈øe you of them, and to be≈øtow vpon you the free pardon and forgiuene≈ø≈øe of them: receiuing the ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øts death as your full ran≈øome: and intreat him mo≈øt earne≈øtly for tho≈øe ≈øinnes, that mo≈øt trouble you. Be≈øeech him to relea≈øe you of all tho≈øe fearefull iudgements of his, which you haue mo≈øt righteou≈ølie de≈øerued, both in this world and in the world to come: and e≈øpecially tho≈øe which you mo≈øt feare: & that he wold ea≈øe you of al tho≈øe publike & priuate calamities, that any wais for your ≈øinnes you are pre≈øently in. P≈øal. 79.8.9. Iona. 3.8. & 1. King. 8.33.36. &c.

Pray for the increa≈øe of your faith, that you may more and more beleeue the forgiuene≈ø≈øe of your ≈øins, by the mini≈øterie of the Go≈øpell, & the v≈øe of his Sacraments: and that you may haue ≈øpeciall faith both in tho≈øe promi≈øes, and for the forgiuene≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe ≈øinnes that you de≈øire mo≈øt of all to be confirmed in. P≈øal. 51.1.7.11.15. & 25.7. Mar. 9.24. And then pray for the≈øe fruites of faith, namely, that you may haue peace of con≈øcience, and quietne≈ø≈øe of minde, knowing that you are
di≈øcharged before gods iudgement ≈øeat: and that you may in the feeling of his loue reioice with an vn≈øpeakable ioy, both aboue all worldlie ioies, and in the mid≈øt of all worldly ≈øorrowes: and thirdly, that you may haue good hope for the time to come, euen in this world mo≈øt of all of your ≈øaluation; and that that may ≈øuffice you. Aske the daily increa≈øe of vnfained repentance for al your ≈øins pa≈øt, and pre≈øent corruptions generally: and more ≈øpecially for all tho≈øe, whereof there is mo≈øt cau≈øe: and not onely that you may be heartily ≈øorie for theÃÑ, but that you may al≈øo hate and loath them, & ≈øtriue mo≈øt earne≈øtly again≈øt them. That you might heereafter preuaile again≈øt ≈øin, and walke in the commandements of God, aske the increa≈øe of the graces of his holie

23. & 2. Cor 5.9. &c.

Then pray for the whole Church of God; and therein for ≈øome parts e≈øpecially, as tho≈øe which are vnder the cro≈ø≈øe, and wherein you doe liue; and herein for ≈øome by name, as the time will permit, and as you haue cau≈øe; as for your Gouernors, high, and low; eccle≈øia≈øticall and ciuill: for your parents, children, friends, and ≈øuch as haue de≈øired your praiers. Secondly for all ≈øins, which are forgiuen you; which you haue beene kept from: and which you haue beene recouered out of. P≈øalm. 103.3. & 51.15. & 16.7. Thirdly for al euill & puni≈øhments, which you haue e≈øcaped aboue others: or which you haue beene deliuered
